contentrichtext.text: {{Expand Chinese|徐四民|date=June 2011}} '''Tsui Sze Man''' ({{zh|c=徐四民|p=Xú Sìmín}}, 3 July 1914 – 9 September 2007) was a pro-[[Beijing]] loyalist and [[magazine]] [[publisher]] based in [[Hong Kong]].<ref name=iht>{{cite news |first=|last=|title= Report: Xu Simin, Beijing loyalist and Hong Kong magazine publisher, dies at 93 |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/09/10/asia/AS-GEN-Hong-Kong-Obit-Xu.php|work= [[Associated Press]] |publisher=[[International Herald Tribune]]|date=2007-09-09 |accessdate=2007-09-18}}</ref> He was nicknamed "Big Cannon Tsui" for his outspoken and sometimes controversial views.<ref name=iht2>{{cite news |first=|last=|title= Hong Kong, Chinese officials bid farewell to Beijing loyalist Xu Simin |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/09/18/asia/AS-GEN-Hong-Kong-Xu-Simin-Funeral.php|work= Associated Press |publisher=International Herald Tribune|date=2007-09-17 |accessdate=2007-09-18}}</ref> He was known as a staunch supporter of Beijing's policies in Hong Kong. ==Early life== Tsui was born in 1914 in [[Burma]] (present day [[Myanmar]]).<ref name=iht/> Despite his birth in Burma, Tsui spent the majority of his life either in mainland [[China]] or Hong Kong. Tsui attended school at [[Xiamen University]] in [[Fujian province]].<ref name=iht/> ==Career== Tsui returned to his birthplace, Burma, in the 1940s and founded the [[New Rangoon News]].<ref name=iht/> He returned to [[Communist]] China in 1964.<ref name=iht/> Tsui finally settled permanently in Hong Kong in 1977. Once in Hong Kong, Tsui began publishing [[The Mirror (Chinese magazine)|The Mirror]], a pro-Beijing magazine which supported the policies of the mainland.<ref name=iht/> Tsui was known for his controversial opinions. In 1998, he heavily criticized [[RTHK]], a Hong Kong government run [[radio station]], for being too critical of the Hong Kong and Chinese administrations. Tsui urged Hong Kong officials to censor RTHK.<ref name=iht2/> Tsui served as a member of the Standing Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, a Hong Kong committee which advises China's congress.<ref name=iht2/> Tsui died of organ failure on 9 September 2007 in Hong Kong at the age of 93.<ref name=iht2/> At Tsui's funderal, [[Gao Siren]], Beijing's liaison to Hong Kong praised Tsui for his support of Hong Kong's [[Hong Kong Basic Law|Basic Law]] and current "[[one country, two systems]]" policy.<ref name=iht2/> Mourners included high level officials from China and Hong Kong's governments, including the [[Chief Executive of Hong Kong]], [[Donald Tsang]], the director of China's Hong Kong and [[Macau]] affairs office, [[Liao Hui (politician)|Liao Hui]], and former Hong Kong leader, [[Tung Chee-hwa]].<ref name=iht2/> Wreaths and flowers were sent by Chinese President [[Hu Jintao]], Premier [[Wen Jiabao]] and [[Wu Bangguo]], the head of China's congress.<ref name=iht2/> Tsui was buried at [[Dapeng Bay]] in the city of [[Shenzhen]], China.<ref name=iht2/> ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2012}} {{Persondata | name = Xu, Simin | alternative names = | short description = Hong Kong businessman | date of birth = 3 July 1914 | place of birth = | date of death = 9 September 2007 | place of death = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Xu, Simin}} [[Category:1914 births]] [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:Recipients of the Grand Bauhinia Medal]] [[Category:Hong Kong businesspeople]] [[Category:Politics of Hong Kong]] [[Category:Deaths from multiple organ failure]] [[Category:Place of birth missing]] [[Category:Burmese people of Chinese descent]] [[Category:Members of the HKSAR Preparatory Committee]]
